title: Quetzalcoatl
summary: Quetzalcoatl (/ˌkɛtsəlkoʊˈætəl/,[3] /ˌkwɛtsəlkoʊˈɑːtəlˌ -ˈkwɑːtəl/;[4] Spanish: Quetzalcóatl pronounced [ketsalˈkoatl] (listen); Classical Nahuatl: Quetzalcōātl [ket͡saɬ'koːaːt͡ɬ] (modern Nahuatl pronunciation ), in honorific form: Quetzalcōātzin) is a deity in Aztec culture and literature whose name comes from the Nahuatl language and means "Precious serpent" or "Quetzal-feathered Serpent".[5] In the 17th century, Ixtlilxóchitl, a descendant of Aztec royalty and historian of the Nahua people, wrote, "Quetzalcoatl, in its literal sense, means 'serpent of precious feathers', but in the allegorical sense, 'wisest of men'."[6]
